Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides partial support for the 6th NSF Large Facilities Workshop, which will be hosted by the Associated Universities Inc./National Radio Astronomy Observatory (NRAO) at the Array Operations Center in Socorro, New Mexico on April 23-25, 2013. The NSF Large Facilities Workshop has been held annually since 2008 and provides a forum for discussing best practices and sharing lessons learned from operational experiences at the NSF-funded large facilities. The workshop will highlight performance measurements for scientific facilities and establishing measurement processes; experiences with competition of awards for facility management and operations; and various approaches to data management including the curation and distribution of scientific data generated by the facility for legacy use. The workshop will also emphasize fostering close interactions and making new contacts to facilitate continuous improvement in operational aspects of NSF large facilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This report summarizes the 2013 NSF Large Facilities Workshop held April 23-25 2013 in Socorro NM.


The workshop was hosted by National Radio Astronomy Observatory. The workshop focused on three main topics: (1) Performance measurements for scientific facilities, (2) Competition and the scientific facility lifecycle, and (3) Data management and distribution. The general structure was three sessions, each focused on a topic area, consisting of 3-5, 15-20 minute ‘seed’ presentations to set the scene for three 1-2 hour breakout sessions. A fourth session covered some areas of general interest. There were two tours: the Incorporated Research Institutions for Seismology, Program for Array Seismic Studies of the Continental Lithosphere Instrument Center and EarthScope, USArray Array Operations Facility, and the National Radio Astronomy Observatory Karl Jansky Very Large Array. General outcomes from workshop are presented in a compacted format with analysis. The analysis and most of the emphasis is the author’s.


The performance measurement session showed that most NSF facilities use similar performance measurement approaches based on facility operations metrics and bibliometrics (publication metrics and statistics). Workshop participants observed that these metrics are not well linked to either ultimate scientific or societal value, and that it is often difficult to recognize success. They also noted that NSF should help them define metrics and performance measurement approaches. The competition session showed that participants want clearly stated selection criteria and process, as well as a publicized timeline for the implementation of the process to ensure a fair competition. More clarity about the difference between operations scope and innovations, and expert evaluation of financial capability of proposers would also help. Proposal preparation costs and the origin of resources was a significant issue. An advisory committee approach was suggested to frame the goals and objectives of each competition. The data management session produced very lively discussions of the challenges and costs associated with archiving data and exposed significant difference between communities regarding data ownership and the value of older datasets.


Workshop participants had many suggestions for improvements to the format of workshops and for future workshop topics. Suggestions for format changes included using posters or a poster session and a desire for more time for informal discussions. Suggestions for future topics included a desire for science-related contributions from facilities, discussions of mid-level projects, and of the proposal and construction phases of facilities. Other suggested topics included discussions of collaborations, funding and support issues, and NSF or federal issues. There were also suggestions for repeated discussions of areas covered in past workshops including user support, business activities, physical and cyber-security, maintenance and other life-cycle areas including end-of-life. There was general interest in a workshop focused on data management. Overall, future workshops should strive to be more organized and driven
by facility participants and their interests.

The National Radio Astronomy Observatory was pleased to host the 2013 Large Facilities Workshop, and looks forward to the next meeting.
